trans-unit.source: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This page provides instructions to create, configure, start, and delete an Azure Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: This page provides instructions to create, configure, start, and delete an Azure Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Create, start, or delete an Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: In this release, you can create an Application Gateway by using PowerShell or REST API calls.
trans-unit.target: In this release, you can create an Application Gateway by using PowerShell or REST API calls.

trans-unit.source: Azure portal and CLI support will be provided in an upcoming release.
trans-unit.target: Azure portal and CLI support will be provided in an upcoming release.

trans-unit.source: This article walks you through the steps to create and configure, start, and delete an Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: This article walks you through the steps to create and configure, start, and delete an Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin
trans-unit.target: Before you begin

trans-unit.source: Install the latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: Install the latest version of the Azure PowerShell cmdlets using the Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the Download page.
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the Download page.

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have a working virtual network with a valid subnet.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have a working virtual network with a valid subnet.

trans-unit.source: Make sure no virtual machines or cloud deployments are using the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Make sure no virtual machines or cloud deployments are using the subnet.

trans-unit.source: The Application Gateway must be by itself in a virtual network subnet.
trans-unit.target: The Application Gateway must be by itself in a virtual network subnet.

trans-unit.source: The servers which you will configure to use the Application Gateway must exist or have their endpoints created either in the virtual network, or with a public IP/VIP assigned.
trans-unit.target: The servers which you will configure to use the Application Gateway must exist or have their endpoints created either in the virtual network, or with a public IP/VIP assigned.

trans-unit.source: What is required to create an Application Gateway?
trans-unit.target: What is required to create an Application Gateway?

trans-unit.source: When you use ther New-AzureApplicationGateway command to create the Application Gateway, no configuration is set at this point and the newly created resource will have to be configured either using XML or a configuration object.
trans-unit.target: When you use ther New-AzureApplicationGateway command to create the Application Gateway, no configuration is set at this point and the newly created resource will have to be configured either using XML or a configuration object.

trans-unit.source: The values are:
trans-unit.target: The values are:

trans-unit.source: Back end server pool: The list of IP addresses of the back end servers.
trans-unit.target: Back end server pool: The list of IP addresses of the back end servers.

trans-unit.source: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the virtual network subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.
trans-unit.target: The IP addresses listed should either belong to the virtual network subnet, or should be a public IP/VIP.

trans-unit.source: Back end server pool settings: Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie-based affinity.
trans-unit.target: Back end server pool settings: Every pool has settings like port, protocol, and cookie-based affinity.

trans-unit.source: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.
trans-unit.target: These settings are tied to a pool and are applied to all servers within the pool.

trans-unit.source: Front end Port: This port is the public port opened on the Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Front end Port: This port is the public port opened on the Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the back end servers.
trans-unit.target: Traffic hits this port, and then gets redirected to one of the back end servers.

trans-unit.source: Listener: The listener has a front end port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).
trans-unit.target: Listener: The listener has a front end port, a protocol (Http or Https, these are case-sensitive), and the SSL certificate name (if configuring SSL offload).

trans-unit.source: Rule: The rule binds the listener and the back end server pool and defines which back end server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.
trans-unit.target: Rule: The rule binds the listener and the back end server pool and defines which back end server pool the traffic should be directed to when it hits a particular listener.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only the basic rule is supported.
trans-unit.target: Currently, only the basic rule is supported.

trans-unit.source: The basic rule is round-robin load distribution.
trans-unit.target: The basic rule is round-robin load distribution.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Create a new Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: There is an order of steps you will have to follow to create an Application Gateway:
trans-unit.target: There is an order of steps you will have to follow to create an Application Gateway:

trans-unit.source: Create Application Gateway resource.
trans-unit.target: Create Application Gateway resource.

trans-unit.source: Create configuration XML file or configuration object.
trans-unit.target: Create configuration XML file or configuration object.

trans-unit.source: Commit the configuration to newly created Application Gateway resource.
trans-unit.target: Commit the configuration to newly created Application Gateway resource.

trans-unit.source: Create an Application Gateway Resource
trans-unit.target: Create an Application Gateway Resource

trans-unit.source: To create the gateway, use the New-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: To create the gateway, use the New-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: Note that billing for the gateway does not start at this point.
trans-unit.target: Note that billing for the gateway does not start at this point.

trans-unit.source: Billing begins in a later step, when the gateway is successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing begins in a later step, when the gateway is successfully started.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new Application Gateway using a virtual network called "testvnet1" and a subnet called "subnet-1".
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new Application Gateway using a virtual network called "testvnet1" and a subnet called "subnet-1".

trans-unit.source: Description, InstanceCount, and GatewaySize are optional parameters.
trans-unit.target: Description, InstanceCount, and GatewaySize are optional parameters.

trans-unit.source: To validate that the gateway was created, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To validate that the gateway was created, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The default value for InstanceCount is 2, with a maximum value of 10.
trans-unit.target: The default value for InstanceCount is 2, with a maximum value of 10.

trans-unit.source: The default value for GatewaySize is Medium.
trans-unit.target: The default value for GatewaySize is Medium.

trans-unit.source: You can choose between Small, Medium and Large.
trans-unit.target: You can choose between Small, Medium and Large.

trans-unit.source: Vip and DnsName are shown as blank because the gateway has not started yet.
trans-unit.target: Vip and DnsName are shown as blank because the gateway has not started yet.

trans-unit.source: These will be created once the gateway is in the running state.
trans-unit.target: These will be created once the gateway is in the running state.

trans-unit.source: Configure Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Configure Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: You can configure Application Gateway using XML or a configuration object.
trans-unit.target: You can configure Application Gateway using XML or a configuration object.

trans-unit.source: Configure Application Gateway using XML
trans-unit.target: Configure Application Gateway using XML

trans-unit.source: In the following example, you will use an XML file to configure all Application Gateway settings and commit them to the Application Gateway resource.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, you will use an XML file to configure all Application Gateway settings and commit them to the Application Gateway resource.

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Copy the following text to Notepad.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following text to Notepad.

trans-unit.source: Edit the values between the parenthesis for the configuration items.
trans-unit.target: Edit the values between the parenthesis for the configuration items.

trans-unit.source: Save the file with extension .xml
trans-unit.target: Save the file with extension .xml

trans-unit.source: The protocol item Http or Https is case sensitive.
trans-unit.target: The protocol item Http or Https is case sensitive.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to use a configuration file to set up the Application Gateway to load balance Http traffic on public port 80 and send network traffic to back end port 80 between 2 IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to use a configuration file to set up the Application Gateway to load balance Http traffic on public port 80 and send network traffic to back end port 80 between 2 IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll set the Application Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll set the Application Gateway.

trans-unit.source: You will use the Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig cmdlet with a configuration XML file.
trans-unit.target: You will use the Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig cmdlet with a configuration XML file.

trans-unit.source: Configure Application Gateway using a configuration object
trans-unit.target: Configure Application Gateway using a configuration object

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to configure the Application Gateway using configuration objects.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to configure the Application Gateway using configuration objects.

trans-unit.source: All configuration items have to be configured individually and then added to an Application Gateway configuration object.
trans-unit.target: All configuration items have to be configured individually and then added to an Application Gateway configuration object.

trans-unit.source: After creating the configuration object, you will use the Set-AzureApplicationGateway command to commit the configuration to the previously created Application Gateway resource.
trans-unit.target: After creating the configuration object, you will use the Set-AzureApplicationGateway command to commit the configuration to the previously created Application Gateway resource.

trans-unit.source: Before assigning a value to each configuration object, you need to declare what kind of object PowerShell uses for storage.
trans-unit.target: Before assigning a value to each configuration object, you need to declare what kind of object PowerShell uses for storage.

trans-unit.source: The first line to create the individual items defines what Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Commands.ServiceManagement.Network.ApplicationGateway.Model(object name) will be used.
trans-unit.target: The first line to create the individual items defines what Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Commands.ServiceManagement.Network.ApplicationGateway.Model(object name) will be used.

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Create all individual configuration items.
trans-unit.target: Create all individual configuration items.

trans-unit.source: Create front end IP as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: Create front end IP as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Create front end port as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: Create front end port as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Create back end server pool
trans-unit.target: Create back end server pool

trans-unit.source: Define the IP addresses which will be added to the back end server pool as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Define the IP addresses which will be added to the back end server pool as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: Using the $server object, add the values to the back end pool object ($pool).
trans-unit.target: Using the $server object, add the values to the back end pool object ($pool).

trans-unit.source: Create back end server pool setting
trans-unit.target: Create back end server pool setting

trans-unit.source: Create listener
trans-unit.target: Create listener

trans-unit.source: Create rule
trans-unit.target: Create rule

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Assign all individual configuration items to a Application Gateway configuration object ($appgwconfig):
trans-unit.target: Assign all individual configuration items to a Application Gateway configuration object ($appgwconfig):

trans-unit.source: Add front end IP to the configuration
trans-unit.target: Add front end IP to the configuration

trans-unit.source: Add front end port to the configuration
trans-unit.target: Add front end port to the configuration

trans-unit.source: Add back end server pool to the configuration
trans-unit.target: Add back end server pool to the configuration

trans-unit.source: Add back end pool setting to the configuration
trans-unit.target: Add back end pool setting to the configuration

trans-unit.source: Add listener to the configuration
trans-unit.target: Add listener to the configuration

trans-unit.source: Add rule to the configuration
trans-unit.target: Add rule to the configuration

trans-unit.source: Step 3
trans-unit.target: Step 3

trans-unit.source: Commit the configuration object to the Application Gateway resource using Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig.
trans-unit.target: Commit the configuration object to the Application Gateway resource using Set-AzureApplicationGatewayConfig.

trans-unit.source: Start the gateway
trans-unit.target: Start the gateway

trans-unit.source: Once the gateway has been configured, use the Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to start the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Once the gateway has been configured, use the Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to start the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Billing for an Application Gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.
trans-unit.target: Billing for an Application Gateway begins after the gateway has been successfully started.

trans-unit.source: The Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: The Start-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet might take up to 15-20 minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway status
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway status

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to check the status of the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to check the status of the gateway.

trans-unit.source: If Start-AzureApplicationGateway succeeded in the previous step, the State should be Running, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.
trans-unit.target: If Start-AzureApplicationGateway succeeded in the previous step, the State should be Running, and the Vip and DnsName should have valid entries.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows an Application Gateway that is up, running, and ready to take traffic destined to http://.cloudapp.net.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows an Application Gateway that is up, running, and ready to take traffic destined to http://.cloudapp.net.

trans-unit.source: Delete an Application Gateway
trans-unit.target: Delete an Application Gateway

trans-unit.source: To delete an Application Gateway:
trans-unit.target: To delete an Application Gateway:

trans-unit.source: Use the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to stop the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to stop the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Verify the gateway has been removed by using the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Verify the gateway has been removed by using the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the Stop-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet on the first line, followed by the output.

trans-unit.source: Once the Application Gateway is in a Stopped state, use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the service.
trans-unit.target: Once the Application Gateway is in a Stopped state, use the Remove-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet to remove the service.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the service has been removed, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the service has been removed, you can use the Get-AzureApplicationGateway cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This step is not required.
trans-unit.target: This step is not required.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure SSL offload, see <link><linkText>Configure Application Gateway for SSL offload</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure SSL offload, see <link><linkText>Configure Application Gateway for SSL offload</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to configure an Application Gateway to use with ILB, see <link><linkText>Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to configure an Application Gateway to use with ILB, see <link><linkText>Create an Application Gateway with an Internal Load Balancer (ILB)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:
trans-unit.target: If you want more information about load balancing options in general, see:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Load Balancer</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Load Balancer</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Traffic Manager</linkText><title></title></link>
